3.06.text:
Hello and welcome to this pre-recorded event
for 15PAS02

14.88.text:
To help you get the most out of this feedback,
you may want to have the following documents

21.44.text:
handy as we will refer to them during the
session.

27.42.text:
Principal moderators report
2015 and the unit 6 assessment criteria document

38.52.text:
The aim of this course is to explain the assessment
criteria for unit 6 A level biology. The course

49.19.text:
will look at some exemplars of candidates'
work to carry out practice assessment exercises

54.56.text:
and address common issues and frequently asked
questions.

63.04.text:
The course will consider:
The principles of unit 6 assessment.

89.41.text:
The need for hierarchical marking.
Explanation of the criteria.

90.45.text:
Consideration of some assessed exemplars and
standardising.

91.32.text:
The assessment of unit 6 covers the AO3 requirements
of the syllabus. The maximum raw mark is 45.

97.16.text:
This equates to 20% of the available A marks
or 10% of the marks for the GCE certification.

106.13.text:
There are two options for teachers.
Option 1A here teachers mark the investigations

115.11.text:
of all their candidates and submit the marks
to Edexcel. A sample of the investigations

121.94.text:
is then moderated by Edexcel.
Alternatively Option 1B The centre sends all

130.64.text:
the candidates' investigations directly to
be marked by Edexcel.

131.71.text:
The maximum mark for each section of the unit
6 criteria are as follows:

132.53.text:
Research and rationale 11 marks.
Planning 11 marks.

143.58.text:
Observing and recording 8 marks.
Interpreting and evaluation 9 marks.

167.26.text:
The most important principle is that the assessment
is not just a simple 'done that' tick box

176.95.text:
exercise. Quality judgements should be made.
The examplars that follow attempt to illustrate

184.90.text:
how candidates' work match the criteria. A
good quality report will show clear progression

192.42.text:
to A2 standards of knowledge and understanding
of biology.

197.76.text:
This distinguishes between candidates of different
abilities.

201.58.text:
The main reason for differences between centre
marks and moderator assessment relates to

211.09.text:
The criteria are difficult and demanding.
This is allowed for by the grade boundaries

222.68.text:
shown. After the report is marked the total
to be awarded should be compared to the grade

229.48.text:
boundaries. If a candidate is awarded 34 marks
is there enough evidence of how science works

237.91.text:
skills to justify an A grade? Marks of 38
or more should only be given for exceptional

246.27.text:
Marks for each section are awarded in a hierarchical
fashion. This means that the subsections for

263.29.text:
each section must met the criteria for a mark
range before the mark for the section. This

265.99.text:
means each subsection must be assessed individually
before an overall mark is selected.

274.99.text:
For example, a teacher mark for the planning
section od a report is as follows.

290.47.text:
P sub section a mark range 7-9b, 7-9c, 3-6
planning limited by poor trial.

302.83.text:
So the maximum mark for planning overall is
6. As the teacher felt that c was very limited

311.62.text:
the work would probably have been given 5
for planning. It could even have been given

318.93.text:
We shall now consider each section in more
detail. The research and rationale section

327.68.text:
must be marked with reference to the following
quality points.

333.90.text:
The biological background should be relevant
to the actual hypothesis being investigated.

341.44.text:
For example some candidates provide long accounts
of all the stages of photosynthesis when they

348.66.text:
are investigating the effect of light intensity.
Complete account of respiration biochemistry

355.49.text:
are often seen which are largely irrelevant.
There must be evidence of understanding the

362.40.text:
biology underpinning the investigation at
A2 level.

367.75.text:
The biological background should lead towards
a rationale to show why the investigation

375.94.text:
might be of interest to biologists.
There must be clear evidence of research.To

381.72.text:
award more than 6 marks there must be evidence
that the research is used to help planning

387.84.text:
the investigation and also in the interpretation
of the results (Ib).

396.70.text:
Now look at exemplars 1 and 2 with the criteria
document to hand.

417.32.text:
This type of investigation is quite regularly
carried out. Some investigations involving

433.50.text:
caffeine are only a small step away from a
core practical. However in this case the research

441.20.text:
is nearly all relevant to the hypothesis stated
on page 2 and some sources were used to support

449.09.text:
Several scientific journals were used and
carefully referenced throughout this section.

455.14.text:
At least some of the biology described clearly
related to A2 topics and was of a suitable

464.57.text:
So strand a was awarded 7-9. Strand b was
limiting as one source was used in the limitations

475.80.text:
section. The range 3-6 was felt to be appropriate.
Overall a strong 6, possibly 7

490.37.text:
This is a common approach to fieldwork. There
can be a potential problem if several candidates

498.89.text:
carry out a similar investigation as their
research and rationale can be quite similar.

504.78.text:
This can limit the marks that can be awarded
for this section.

509.65.text:
This example has very little irrelevant biology.
The information about respiration and ATP

518.43.text:
had been carefully selected rather than just
giving a generic description of aerobic respiration.

524.44.text:
Sources were clearly used here and to support
the conclusions.

529.97.text:
Stand a - was in the range 7-9 and strand
b had just enough sources to justify a mark

547.45.text:
Detailed descriptions of basic apparatus are
not required. All the important variables

553.91.text:
must be identified and discussed. Risks need
to be assessed and steps taken to minimise

561.59.text:
the risks. Remember basic laboratory rules
do not constitute a risk assessment.

569.08.text:
Methods from core practicals are not evidence
of individual skills. Methods for bacterial

577.04.text: work can also be a problem here.

580.42.text:
Sub section c is often the weakest section
of planning. It frequently limits the overall

592.22.text:
mark for this section. A good trial is likely
to focus on the main dependent and independent

599.54.text:
variables. Are these variables being measured
reliably and accurately?

605.86.text:
Some trial data must be presented. This information
should be the basis of logical decision making.

614.79.text:
Large quantities of data are not required.
The final data collection method should show

626.69.text:
some sensible modifications in the light of
the trial data.

628.99.text:
Now look at exemplar3 with the criteria document
to hand.

655.28.text:
This was an original piece of work. The method
omitted one or two pieces of information.

662.73.text:
However the candidate did not rely on the
work of other enthusiasts, the plan had a

666.99.text:
The risk assessment was centred around animal
welfare and the work carried out legally.

674.11.text:
There was a well considered trial that informed
the final data collection. Consider what was

686.84.text:
All three stands were in the 7-9 range and
9 was awarded overall.

695.73.text:
Data should be recorded in a clear table with
units. All the raw data must be shown to support

707.70.text:
any summary tables. Anomalous results must
be identified. If there are no anomalous results

715.99.text:
there should be a statement to that effect
to confirm careful inspection of the data

721.72.text:
collected.
To gain the highest marks (b7-8) any anomalies

725.76.text:
need to be investigated. If his is not possible
then at least some actions should be taken,

735.33.text:
such as removing the anomalies from calculations
or retaining them. Some brief reasoning is

742.52.text: needed to support the action taken.

745.41.text:
Now look at exemplar 4 and 5 with the criteria
document to hand.

777.22.text:
Lots of data, of which this is a sample only,
but misses several requirements for O(a) and

782.73.text:
O(a) Obviously the table should not have had
ant symbols and there is endless repetition

793.69.text:
of mean. Towards the bottom of the second
table there is an error in the LUX value as

800.03.text:
1019.4 is repeated three times. All the other
LUX values are whole numbers. This was a careless

809.09.text:
error that could have been corrected by careful
proofreading.

812.99.text:
There was no comment about anomalies either
being present or absent. Stand a was in the

821.36.text:
range 3-6 and strand b 3-6 with a benefit
of doubt about anomalies.

836.94.text:
Both strands were 7-8 as sufficient data had
been collected a there was a mathematical

845.19.text:
test for anomalies with a suitable comment
on the next page. Overall 8 marks.

852.83.text:
The statistical test must show how the statistic
was calculated and not just the final value.

864.11.text:
This may be in the form of calculations by
hand or a detailed table of computer generated

871.30.text:
calculations. The chosen statistical test
must be appropriate to the investigation.

877.49.text:
Good plans how the date is going to be tested.
A null hypothesis must be stated and the candidate

886.12.text:
should state, in their own words, how they
have interpreted the result of the statistical

893.44.text:
Explaining the data using biological principles
is an important sub section that is frequently

905.17.text:
too brief to allow movement beyond the mark
range 0-3.

909.01.text:
Candidates should discuss the data collected
and this should be linked to some of the research

916.37.text:
information they gathered. The data collected
does not have to agree with information from

922.19.text:
a research source but there must be evidence
that the findings have been compared to other

929.47.text:
The evaluation sub section c can be problematic
for candidates. General comments relating

941.51.text:
the findings to the research and rationale
will limit the marks that can be awarded here.

947.36.text:
To enter the higher mark ranges an analytical
evidence-based evaluation is needed.

952.98.text:
Evidence can be in the form of ;
the presence or absence of anomalies, standard

962.20.text:
deviations, patterns in graphs, the of problem
of linking a correlation with a causation,

972.14.text:
uncontrollable variables (not errors of planning!),
problems of extrapolating results to other

978.57.text:
situations e.g. from an animal model to humans
and the limitations of a single investigation

987.18.text:
Now read exemplars 6 and 7 with the criteria
document to hand.

992.55.text:
The statistical analysis included calculations
in the appendix and here the account statistics

1014.34.text: with a correct summary of findings.

1031.42.text:
The comments on biological principles are
relevant to the data collected and at the

1039.41.text:
standard expected for A2. A source has been
used towards the bottom of the first page,

1044.61.text:
although more than one link to research sources
is desirable. The evaluation considered significant

1052.74.text: limitations and further work was suggested.

1055.93.text:
All three strands were in the range 7-9. Overall
8 marks were awarded.

1067.06.text:
The candidate gave a conclusion that was contradicted
by the statistical tests and the biology is

1076.49.text: not at a2 standard. Ib was in the range 0-3

1082.27.text:
What is required here is not just a simple
repetition of what was in the introductory

1089.61.text:
research but an application of this research
to the actual data collected. This is a section

1097.31.text:
where we expect evidence of A2 progression
showing understanding of the biology and applying

1118.78.text:
a clear objective approach to what has been
shown and what has not. Conditional language

1121.60.text:
such as 'supports the idea that' is really
helpful as is avoiding statements like 'prove

1128.95.text:
The communication section has four sub sections.
Sub section (a) usually presents candidates

1135.97.text:
with few problems.
Sub section (b) has more candidates remaining

1140.54.text:
in lower mark ranges due to errors such as
careless tabulation.

1146.31.text:
The selection and presentation of graphs is
often surprisingly weak with even basics such

1153.17.text:
as labelling axes poor.
Multiple pointless graphs, often with incorrect

1159.40.text:
formats, are seen rather quite frequently.
A suitable summary graph with range or error

1165.93.text:
bars carefully labelled allows the award of
high marks assuming all the other aspects

1175.93.text:
This slide shows a graph that seeks to impress.
In fact it does not reveal any trend or pattern

1187.49.text:
in the data so no conclusion about upper and
lower shore specimens is possible. A graph

1195.28.text:
of mean height for upper and lower shore with
error bars is the correct format here.

1206.25.text:
Sub section (c) requires a 'properly constructed
bibliography' for 3-4 marks. Unfortunately

1215.26.text:
many bibliographies are not in a scientifically
recognised form.

1221.52.text:
Meaningless web addresses are commonly included.
Candidates give the source of a scientific

1228.31.text:
journal but do not name it. Without a scientific
journal as a source this sub section and thus

1235.50.text:
the whole of section C is limited to the mark
range 0-2.

1240.62.text:
Unfortunately for sub section (d) many candidates
demonstrate little progression to A2 level

1249.49.text:
in evaluating sources. Candidates frequently
only comment on the possibility of

1255.98.text:
bias in a source. The process of peer review
needs to be explained to the reader. Cross

1263.32.text:
referencing between sources (especially scientific
journals) is not particularly difficult but

1270.16.text:
is rarely seen.
Not all sources need to be evaluated, quality

1276.24.text:
not quantity is required as evidence of this
skill.

1281.05.text:
This slide shows the standard required for
the bibliography.

1289.85.text:
Journal
Author, Initials., Year. Title of article.

1291.29.text:
Full Title of Journal, Volume number (Issue/Part
number), Page numbers.

1294.59.text:
Correct e.g.
Kelly D.W, Dick J.T.A, Montgomery W.I, 2002.

1296.45.text:
The functional role of Gammarus, Hydrobiologica,
485, 199-203.

1298.10.text:
Many examples of very poor bibliographies
are seen.

1304.43.text:
Aggregating marks should be carried out as
follows:

1311.56.text:
A mark range for each sub-section of a single
criterion must be recorded.

1316.69.text:
Only then can a single criterion mark be assessed.
Remember that marks within each criterion

1325.54.text:
are aggregated in a hierarchical manner.
This is explained further in the following

1331.59.text:
slide.
Always consider the final total, is this reasonable

1337.80.text:
for this report? Does it reflect a fair A2
grade?

1344.71.text:
Difficult borderline decisions are bound to
occur when assessing so be fair and be consistent.

1356.16.text:
The first difficult decision met , say mark
range 4-6 or 7-9, give the benefit of the

1364.88.text:
doubt as a weak 7-9
BUT the next time this problem is met then

1370.33.text:
do not move to the higher range and so on.
In this way marks will be fair and will not

1378.02.text:
drift well away from what a moderator might
award

1381.47.text:
Internal standardisation must be evident on
the sample of candidates' work sent to Edexcel

1394.36.text:
for moderation. All the teachers involved
in marking the work should take part.

1401.85.text:
All participants must be able to express an
opinion and to accept the views of others.

1407.46.text:
All participants have read through the 'Internal
Assessment Guide', feedback reports from examiners/moderators

1415.54.text:
and recent examiners reports.
The meeting takes place before any live assessment

1424.30.text:
is undertaken.
Participants assess at least one common exemplar

1428.57.text:
completely independently, before the meeting.
The best indicator of a productive meeting

1436.48.text:
is disagreement which is discussed and resolved.
Poor standardisation is characterised by quiet

1445.69.text:
Many significant issues have been repeatedly
commented upon in the internal assessment

1456.38.text:
guide and several examiner's reports in recent
years, yet these are still very common.

1464.12.text:
Repeating core practicals with little evidence
of individual planning or understanding.

1470.89.text:
Core practicals are vehicles for training
in How Science Works skills not 'perfect'

1479.10.text:
examples or demonstrations- many have significant
flaws which need to be objectively evaluated.

1488.69.text:
A lack of A2 level understanding of the biological
principles involved, especially 'growth' and

1498.69.text:
There are lots of other exemplars and further
guidance in the following 2 documents which

1508.24.text:
are available to download at the end of this
presentation.

1513.31.text:
Internal Assessment Guide Biology
6BI06 Examiner's / Moderator's report June

1522.32.text:
2015 which was written to provide further
exemplification

1527.22.text:
For more information, please contact subject
advisors,

1538.34.text:
subject pages/communities and ask the expert.
Ask the expert usually resolves problems quickly.

1547.70.text:
If you would like to know more about examination
statistics, you may find these links of interest

1561.65.text:
www.edexcel.com/iwantto/Pages/stats.aspx
Results statistics summarise the overall grade

1564.40.text:
outcomes of candidates sitting Edexcel
examinations.

1572.88.text:
This page shows the minimum marks needed to
achieve a certain grade for all UK and international

1581.54.text:
examinations.
Also refer to the examiners report which is

1585.22.text: available for download with other documents.

1588.20.text:
ResultsPlus is Edexcel's free online service
giving instant and detailed analysis of your

1596.14.text:
students' exam and mock performance. Here
you can see your students' scores for every

1608.75.text:
exam question and understand how your students'
performance compares with Edexcel national

1618.79.text:
There is a wide portfolio of training events
already scheduled for the academic year 2014/15.

1631.77.text:
These include training events for our General
Qualifications as well as Vocational Qualifications.

1637.90.text:
For General Qualifications, you can take an
advantage of events such as:

1643.97.text:
Delivering the qualification.
Getting Ready to Teach.

1649.29.text:
Guidance on internally assessed units.
Controlled Assessment.

1656.24.text:
Standardization.
Our events have been designed for the UK as

1659.61.text:
well as international centres. Some events
that are specifically designed for UK centres

1662.26.text: and some specifically for international centres
